Award.AwardTitle: Neuro-Cognitive Studies of Sleep and the Generalization of Emotional Learning and Threat Detection

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to encode emotionally laden memories and exploit them efficiently in novel situations is among the most important learning capabilities of an individual. From correct recognition of facial expressions in emotionally-charged social situations, to discrimination between threatening and safe signals in fight-or-flight scenarios, the way we build on our past emotional experiences to decipher unfamiliar conditions strongly determines our ability to survive and function adaptively. Contemporary research on sleep and memory indicates that sleep plays a key role in the generalization of past experiences to novel situations, a process involving core brain regions such as the hippocampus, amygdala and medial prefrontal cortex. However, significant inconsistencies exist between findings regarding the effect of sleep on emotional versus non-emotional memories. These inconsistencies pose a significant obstacle for reaching a comprehensive understanding of how sleep affects memory and learning in general, and how it differentially affect fear memories in particular. Understanding how sleep assists processing of emotional memories can bridge those gaps, as well as contribute broader knowledge to inform any future developments in prevention and treatment of anxiety disorders that involve both sleep and memory generalization disruptions, specifically post-traumatic stress disorder for which sleep irregularities have been emphasized as a key factor.

Current studies suggest that generalizing acquired associations of non-emotional stimuli to novel situations is influenced by a specific sleep stage termed Slow-Wave-Sleep (SWS). Processing of emotional stimuli, on the other hand, was shown to be influenced mostly by another sleep stage, Rapid-Eye-Movement (REM) sleep. These potential inconsistencies raise the question of how sleep influences processes requiring a combination of the two, namely, generalization of emotional memories. These issues, however, were only sporadically addressed in human studies, and were mainly concentrated on a narrow definition of memory generalization. The current project will attempt to elucidate the mechanism involved in the way sleep affects fear generalization and threat detection in humans, addressing the empirical and theoretical gaps by: (1) Employing long-term monitoring of sleep stages prior to, and following, fear learning, that may be more sensitive in detecting relations between cognitive mechanisms and sleep characteristics compared to studies using only single-night monitoring (2) Using novel neurocognitive assessments of fear generalization processes, focusing on discriminative learning of threat and safe stimuli, accompanied by functional neuroimaging (fMRI); (3) Studying computational network models of the key brain regions known to be involved in fear learning to simulate and interpret the experimental findings. These three approaches will allow establishing how fear generalization is affected by individual baselines of sleep patterns, whether it is differently affected by the type of stimuli generalization (discriminative versus similarity-based) required by the behavioral task, and what the level of involvement of the key brain regions is in each type of generalization task and in relation to the individual sleep patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to encode emotionally laden memories and exploit them efficiently in novel situations is among the most important learning capabilities of an individual. From correct recognition of facial expressions in emotionally-charged social situations, to discrimination between threatening and safe signals in fight-or-flight scenarios, the way we build on our past emotional experiences to decipher unfamiliar conditions strongly determines our ability to survive and function adaptively. Contemporary research on sleep and memory indicates that sleep plays a key role in the recall and consolidation of emotional memories, a process involving core brain regions such as the amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex. In particular, sleep significantly contributes to the recall of fearful experiences and their generalization to novel situations. Damage to this mechanism is thought to contribute to the development of several anxiety disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)

Previous research into the way sleep modulates fear memories is nevertheless limited in several crucial aspects. First, it did not specify whether regular patterns of sleep, characterizing the individual on a day-to-day basis prior to experiencing a fearful event, affect the subsequent acquisition of fear memories. Second, it remained unclear whether sleep could help discriminate between elements in the environment that predict upcoming threats and those that signal safety. Both questions tap into the basic mechanisms through which sleep asserts its effect on fear memories and could therefore have implications for understanding the development of anxiety disorders.

To answer these questions, we ran four experiments that directly address the gaps in previous knowledge in the field. In the first two experiments, we monitored the baseline sleep of 34 participants for several days and then administered a fear-learning paradigm while scanning their brains (Figure 1A). Results of both experiments indicated that the more baseline Rapid-Eye-Movement sleep (REM; also known as the sleep stage when most dreams appear) individuals had, the lower was their brain response when they encoded a fearful experience ? particularly the activity in areas known to process fear memories such as the amygdala, hippocampus and vmPFC and the connectivity between them (Figure 1B). 

In two other experiments we employed a novel paradigm, in which participants learned to fear multifaceted stimuli that included some signals that strongly predicted threats and some that didn?t. Participants then went to sleep, after which they were administered a test examining how well they discriminate the threat-predicting signals from the ?safe? signals. We found that the more REM sleep between training and testing participants had, the better was their ability to discriminate threats and safety signals. In contrast, more REM sleep was also related to reduced fear memory of the original multifaceted stimuli.

Analyzing our results, we were able to show that a previously published model, the REM recalibration hypothesis, could account for all of these findings. According to this model, REM sleep contributes to the daily restoration of the sensitivity of brain areas devoted for fear processing. With too little REM, sensitivity is disturbed, leading to both an inflated response when encoding new fear memories and to difficulty in detecting the signals that are most predictive of upcoming threats. 

The broader impact of our results can be demonstrated in relation to PTSD. If baseline levels of REM sleep predict how sensitive the brain is when experiencing a fearful event, lower amounts of REM could be considered a risk factor, opening up possibilities for preventative measures. For example, candidates for high-risk positions, such as trainees in military combat units, could have their baseline sleep patterns monitored, and their candidacy would be considered further only if their REM sleep is on the higher end of what is considered to be the normal spectrum. This way, their probability of developing PTSD if they go on to experience a traumatic event during active duty would be reduced. 

Our second main result, showing REM sleep affect fear discrimination abilities, have implications as well ? for example, when embedding it within paradigms involving Targeted Memory Reactivation (TMR). TMR is a recently developed method aimed at influencing the consolidation of memories, including fear memories. It involves having a sensory stimuli associated with memories at wake, and then reapplied during the subsequent sleep period in order to reactivate those memories and lead to their strengthening or weakening. Based on our results, one could attempt training PTSD patients on discriminating between the threatening and safe elements of their traumatic memory, and apply TMR during subsequent REM sleep in order to consolidate this training. A successful outcome may lead to the isolation of external triggers to only those directly related to the traumatic memory, and a general improvement in symptomology.
